subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Look at the fig tree and all the trees. When they sprout leaves, you can see for yourselves and know that summer is near. Even so, when you see these things happening, you know that the kingdom of God is near. (Luke 21:29-31)
reflection: Do you know what a "sure thing" is? Jesus had just finished speaking of the signs that would precede His coming. Signs in nature like floods and earthquakes. Signs in society like wars and rumors of wars. Signs in the church like love for the Word growing cold and false Christ's arising. All these signs, He says, will occur before His return. All these signs, we might say, tell us that His coming is a sure thing. It's going to happen. Have we become so wrapped up in the signs that we have forgotten the reason for them? Have we become so wrapped up in our day to day activities that we haven't even noticed what is happening in nature, in society and even the church??? Yes all these things (signs) are happening, the signs themselves aren't that important ~ BUT Who they point to is, which is the King of course. He wants each of us to be a part of His Kingdom of grace. He wants His gospel to make us His very own. When He does, we are ready for His sure return. Then we can even pray for it to happen.
prayer: Dear Lord, this Advent season let the signs point my heart heavenward to Your return. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Comfort, comfort my people, says your God. Speak tenderly to Jerusalem, and proclaim to her that her hard service has been completed, that her sin has been paid for, that she has received from the Lord's hand double for all her sins. (Isaiah 40:1, 2)
reflection: Yes, Isaiah had "good news" for Israel who was living in captivity. God was going to end her separation from the homeland of Canaan. Better still, He was going to end her separation from Him. Sin separates people from God. It builds a wall no sinner can crawl under, crash through, or climb over. Only the Holy God, from whom sin separates us, can break down that wall. Isaiah was to speak of "double" payment, so completely were her sins gone. We might ask, "How?" Isaiah in many other verses told of the coming virgin's Son. Of the Lamb going silently to the slaughter. Of the One on whom all sins were laid and by whom all sins were paid. Better news than this Israel would never hear, Nor will we. This Advent season it's time to kneel a little closer to Jesus' crib and beneath His cross. There we will hear the best news ever of how God sent Jesus to bring double payment for all our sins.
prayer: Lord, open my heart to receive anew the God News of sins forgiven through Jesus. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Make straight in the wilderness a highway for our God. Every valley shall be raised up, every mountain and hill be made low. (Isaiah 40:3, 4)
reflection: "Every valley shall be raised up, " Isaiah said. When we feel that we have more sin than God has forgiveness, we need Isaiah's words. We need to hear that God's love, like some earth-moving machine, has scooped up Christ's forgiveness and dumped it into our heart's swampy spots. We need to pray ~ away with the doubt that grows in my swamp. Let my heart be filled with the solid news of Jesus' forgiveness."Make straight in the wilderness a highway for our God." Let the world plot its bypasses and curves. The heart in which the Christ Child lives seeks to follow the straight middle line on life's road. The believer wants to walk according to God's Word."Repent and be saved, " read the notice. Underneath, someone had wrote, "If you've already repented, please disregard this notice." That is not so with Advent's road construction. It's necessary year around.
prayer: Dear Lord, knock my heart flat with Your Law, and then build it up with the "Good News of Jesus Christ." Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: In that day you will sing: "Praise the Lord! He was angry with me, but now He comforts me. See God has come to comfort me. I will trust in Him and not be afraid. The Lord God is my strength and my song; He has become my salvation." (Isaiah 12:1, 2)
reflection: If you read all six verses of chapter 12 you will notice its all a hymn of praise. What is the praise about? It is a description of the people's joy when Jesus Christ comes to reign over the earth. Even now we need to express our gratitude to God, thanking Him, and telling others about Him. YES from the depths of our gratitude, we need to be praising Him. AND we should share the Good News with others. The Good News of how God turned His anger away and sent His Son to be our salvation, that is truly a reason for joy.
prayer: Dear Lord help me to share the joy of my salvation. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Give thanks to the Lord, call on His name; make known among the nations what He has done, and proclaim that His name is exalted. (Isaiah 12:4)
reflection: "Give thanks to the Lord, " Isaiah says. Even if we sound like a bullfrog in some pond, we should sing to the One who gave us the newborn King. We should also use our life to thank the great Giver of Christmas."Make known among the nations what He has done, " Isaiah also urged. One sure way to increase Christmas joy is to share it. Not only should we join the carolers at Christmastime in singing "We Wish You a Merry Christmas." We should use every opportunity each day to help bring to others the Good News of the Savior sent by God's love. I want them to have the same Merry Christmas I do, shouldn't you? A Merry Christmas? Yes, when we rejoice in Jesus our Savior and share Him with others.
prayer: Dear Lord, help me to sing loudly all year through. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: See, I will send My messenger, who will prepare the way before Me. Then suddenly the Lord you are seeking will come to His temple. (Mal. 3:1a)
reflection: "Jesus is coming, " Malachi told the Jews of his day. BUT it would still be 400 years before John the Baptist at the Jordan River would prepare people for the Savior's coming. But Malachi wrote as if it were today."Before you know it, the promised Savior will be standing in the midst of His people." Did you notice what Malachi called Him? "The Lord, " he said. The eternal God would come down to the earth He had created to work among the creatures He had made and who in sin had turned away from Him. That my friends is the miracle in the manger. That's the real reason for joy. To often many just see a poor baby wrapped in rags and miss the real meaning of Christmas. They see only a man and actually see nothing. If Jesus were only a human being, we would have no cause to celebrate. Then we could just as well forget about Christmas or change the name of the season to the "holiday whatever." Who's coming this season? The Lord Himself, stooping low in love to save sinners like me.
prayer: Dear Lord, this season help me sing, "Joy to the world, the Lord has come to me." Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: The Messenger of the covenant, whom you desire, will come, says the Lord Almighty. (Mal 3:1b)
reflection: Somewhere I saw a painting of the nativity. Angels gathered round the Christ Child's manger with their songs of praise. But over in the corner one angel, holding a small cross it its hand, was wiping a tear from its eyes. What a reminder! God Himself came to the manger to go to the cross. That's what Malachi tells us. When he calls Jesus the "Messenger of the covenant" he refers to the beautiful one-sided agreement that God made with sinners already in the Garden of Eden. There God Promised to our fallen parents that He would send His Son as the seed of the woman to crush Satan's head. Malachi says with obvious joy, "The Messenger of the covenant [the promised Savior] will come." This blessed season we can echo the prophets words but change the tense. "The Savior has come" By God's grace I can even add as I kneel at His manger bed, "The Savior came for me." For me He left heaven's throne. For me He took on human flesh. To save me He lived and died. If that wonderful news doesn't fill me with joy, I might as well tear the December pages of the calendar or at least cancel the month's last week. Jesus my Savior, is coming again. that's why I celebrate Christmas.
prayer: Dear Lord, help me to sing with joy, Joy to the world the Lord, my Savior, has come. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: But who can endure the day of His coming? Who can stand when He appears? For He will be like a refiner's fire or a launderer's soap. (Mal. 3:2)
reflection: I love working with old ~ OLD tractors, but at the end of the day my hands are black and greasy. but I have a special soap which takes it all away."A launderer's soap, " Malachi called the coming Savior. The word means strong stuff like I have in my shop. Like that soap, the coming Christ would scrub human hearts clean from the impossible-to-remove grease of sin."A refiner's fire, " Malachi also said. Like a super-hot smelter, the coming of Christ would melt sin's impurities from precious human hearts. Hearts that the Savior has purified need not be afraid. They can stand holy when He returns in judgment. BUT hearts that reject the Christ will burn like the fire under the smelting furnace or like the lye eating away at the grease. Because of their unbelief, they will carry their sins into hell's everlasting pain. Who came for me at Christmas? Thank God I can answer, "Jesus, my purifier from sin." Because of Jesus I can say: "I am not what I ought to be. I am not what I wish to be. I am not what I hope to be. BUT by the grace of God I am not what I was."
prayer: Dear Lord, and Savior, wash me clean from sin's grease and power me for the fight against sin. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: So I will come near to you for judgment. I the Lord do not change. (Mal. 3:5, 6)
reflection: Unbeliever's will do more than shrink back when Jesus comes on the Last Day. They may have thought they could hide their sins from the One seemingly far away in the heavens. They may have thought His eyes couldn't see their hearts. But He is near. He does see. And He will punish. That threat is real. The Lord who does not change makes it. He will carry it out. The Judge is coming. No doubt about this fact, for the Lord does not change His mind. Nor will He change the forgiveness with which He covers me or anyone else who has asked Him into their heart. The one who judges me is the One who has already saved me.
prayer: Dear Lord, remind me of my salvation when I think of You as my judge. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: John came. preaching a baptism of repentance for the forgiveness of sins. After me will come one more powerful than I. He will baptize you with the Holy Spirit. (Mark 1:4, 7, 8)
reflection: What if John the Baptist came to be the guest speaker in your church? What would he preach about??? I'm sure he would have something to say about repentance. That means he would talk about my sins. Some seem they would rather ignore sin, putting a blindfold over the eyes of their conscience. They'd rather alibi for sin, pointing to others who are worse. They'd rather sugarcoat sin, dusting it with sweet phrases like, "cultural change." But John would preach sin to me in plain terms. And I had better listen. If the Savior in the manger is going to mean anything to me, and you, we need to know how much we need Him. With even more gusto John would preach about the Savior. In his day he pointed hears all the way ahead to Christ's finished work. John saw Jesus, with His work of salvation finished, ascending back to heaven. He saw the ascended Savior sending His Holy Spirit to bring people to faith. He saw the Savior returning to judge the world. What would he preach to us if he filled the pulpit of our churches today? Above all, he'd say: "Remember the Savior who went to the cross and then back to heaven. Remember how His salvation is complete. Remember how he's coming again to take you to heaven." Let us pray that our pastors will preach John's sermon to us this Advent.
prayer: Dear Lord, remind me of my sins each day so that I may rejoice on the day Jesus comes for me. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Mary was greatly troubled at his words. but the angel said to her, "Do not be afraid, Mary, you have found favor with God." (Luke 1:29, 30)
reflection: Yes Mary was the first one to have Christmas anxiety! Yes, Mary was afraid. But put yourself in her shoes and you will see why. In her day people looked down on unwed pregnant women. Also, what about her fianc Joseph? How would she ever explain it to him? And that holy angel! Sinful people just simply cannot stand in the presence of the holy God. They can't even stand with heads erect before one of God's angels."Do not be afraid, Mary, ' the angel told her, "you have found favor with God." God's favor flows from His grace. Yes this unexplainable pregnancy was the reason for anxiety ~ BUT Jesus was the answer to Mary's Christmas anxiety and can be ours too. Any anxiety in your heart this Advent? The Savior in the manger won't mean much to you if you don't reexamine the reason for His coming. We really need to look past the veneer we paste over our life and into our heart. The sight isn't pretty. We can no more kneel before Jesus' manger than Mary could stand before the angel. But God has favored us too. He sent His Son to remove our sins with His payment. He sent Jesus so we could stand without anxiety before Him this blessed Christmas season.
prayer: Dear Lord remove the fear from my sinful heart. Fill it with joy because of my Savior's birth. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "How will this be, " Mary answered, "since I am a virgin?" The angel answered, "The Holy Spirit will come upon you, and the power of the Most High will overshadow you. So the holy one to be born will be called the Son of God." (Luke 1:34, 35)
reflection: Mary knew biology. She knew it took two people to conceive a baby. She also knew that she was still a virgin. In amazement she had to ask, "How will this be?" the angels answer must have taken her breath away. The Holy Spirit would miraculously begin Jesus' human life in her womb. The virgin birth of Jesus, though disputed by some, is a very important teaching. It reminds us that Jesus was "the Holy One" as the angel told Mary. If you add a human father to Jesus' conception you would eliminate Him as the Savior. From a human father and mother, Jesus would have inherited the same sinful heart that we did. Also, the virgin birth should remind us that it was totally God's work. Man had no part in it. How could man bring about the incredible miracle of God's infinite love taking the infinite shape of true man? Such a love-packed miracle can only be God's great doing. Yes Christmas means amazement ~ Joy beyond measure because of God's love-powered miracles for us.
prayer: Dear Lord, help me sing loudly of Your amazing love and what it has done for me in Jesus. Amen.

"How will this be?" the angels answer must have taken her breath away.
The Holy Spirit would miraculously begin Jesus' human life in her womb...

The virgin birth of Jesus, though disputed by some, is a very important
teaching. It reminds us that Jesus was "the Holy One" as the angel told Mary.
If you add a human father to Jesus' conception you would eliminate Him as 
the Savior...

From a human father and mother, Jesus would have inherited the same
sinful heart that we did. Also, the virgin birth should remind us that it was 
totally God's work. Man had no part in it. How could man bring about the 
incredible miracle of God's infinite love taking the infinite shape of true man?

Such a love-packed miracle can only be God's great doing...
Yes Christmas means amazement ~ Joy beyond measure 
because of God's love-powered miracles for us...

Prayer Suggestion:
Dear Lord, help me sing loudly of Your amazing love
and what it has done for me in Jesus...Amen.

Pastor Al & Marcie Sather

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "I am the Lord's servant, " Mary answered."May it be to me as you have said." (Luke 1:38).
reflection: In 11 more days, Christmas will be here. In 12, Christmas will be past. Is that how it will go this year? Or will Christmas last all year? From Mary we can gain the answer. The angel's holy presence first filled Mary with fear. The angel's awesome message filled her with questions. With both fear and questions erased, Mary had only one reaction. In simple faith she said, "I am the Lord's servant. May it be to me as you have said." As God's humble servant she was willing to follow His commands. She found joy in doing what her servant-God asked of her. When will Christmas end for you? The answer is obvious. Jesus wants to be our Savior throughout our life. He wants to serve us with His forgiveness all our days. He wants to take us to heaven on our final day. So we should want to serve Him all our days. So our question should be, "What can I do for You, Lord Jesus, who has done so much for me?" Willing obedience is the best gift we can give God during our lifelong Christmas.
prayer: Dear Lord, wrap my thoughts and my life around Jesus all the days of my life. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: "Praise be to the Lord, the God of Israel, because He has come and has redeemed His people. He has raised up a horn of salvation for us in the house of His Servant David, to shine on those living in darkness and in the shadow of death, to guide our feet into the path of peace." (Luke 1:68, 69, 79)
reflection: Can you imagine the joy if, when Christmas comes, people everywhere would reevaluate the gifts the Heavenly guest brings in His arms? Zechariah sang of those gifts."He has raised up a horn of salvation, " he said. Like so much garbage, Jesus tossed aside, sin ~ death ~ and the devil forever. Victory over all three are the gifts the Savior brings. Like the rising sun, Zechariah said, "Jesus came to shine on those living in darkness and in the shadow of death." More than a child afraid of the night's darkness, I had to be terrified of sin's blackness. Yes I was scared of death's darkness. No light ~ no hope ~ no joy ~ no heaven ~ no nothing ~ without the Savior at the door this blessed season. Does salvation's light seem as bright as ever? If not, it's time to go back to square one, to ask ourselves: "Am I a sinner? How much, not how little, Have I sinned? Where do I deserve to go because of my sins? What would death be like without Jesus? Then perhaps we'll be ready to sing with joy, "The happy Christmas comes once more, the Heavenly Guest with His precious gifts is at the door.
prayer: Dear Lord, and blessed Savior, let Your salvation light up my Christmas and my heart with joy. Amen

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: 74 to rescue us from the hand of our enemies, and to enable us to serve him without fear 75 in holiness and righteousness before him all our days. (Luke 1:74-75)
reflection: Have you ever noticed that there are very few purple Christmas bulbs? There are all kinds of red, yellow, and blue ones. Someone once explained that purple glass cuts off light waves and as a result dims the brightness. And, of course, we want the lights of Christmas to shine. Isn't that what Zechariah tells us in our verse? He reminds us that the Savior comes to "enable us to serve Him without fear in holiness and righteousness before Him all our days." Have you ever given any thought to the fact that Christians are to be Christmas bulbs shinning brightly long after Christmas passes??? As a believer in Christ, I'm to shine, not because I'm forced to but because I have to. It's the very nature of those who are plugged in to the Light of the world, to shine with His light. And there is no switch that turns me off so that I shine only once in a while."ALL OUR DAYS, " Zechariah said.
prayer: Dear Heavenly Guest, thank you for the light of salvation. Help me shine it to others. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Rejoice in the Lord always. I will say again: Rejoice! (Philippians 4:4)
reflection: Rejoice? Isn't that what the Christmas season is all about? What a shame it only comes once a year. Paul wasn't thinking about people or presents when he encouraged believers at Philippi, "to rejoice always." How could he have been? The apostle was imprisoned at Rome, jailed unjustly for the crime of talking about his Savior. Oh he knew what the usual exit from a Roman jail was ~ a head lost to the executioner's axe. Yet he urged his fellow believers, "Rejoice always." "In the Lord, " he reminded them. Here my friends is the key for joy that lasts from one Christmas to the next. As Paul put it, "You know the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that though He was rich, yet for our sakes He became poor, so that you through His poverty might become rich." (2 Corinthians 8:9). And then he added, "Thanks be to God for His indescribable gift." (2 Corinthians 9:15). As believers we have a joy that never ends because we have a God whose grace is unending. In Jesus He gave us the best gift He had, the Savior from sin in whom we can rejoice every day of our life.
prayer: Dear Lord, thank You for the gift of Your Son as my Savior. Fill me with joy because of Him. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Let your gentleness be evident to all. The Lord is near. (Philippians 4:5)
reflection: How big is Christmas to you? Is it just sharing a greeting, sending a card? What are your thoughts this time of the year? Is it what will I get from others? What I gave them last year cost more than what they gave me? Such thinking exhibits not a spirit of gentle concern for others but selfish concerns for self. Such thoughts rob one of the Christmas joy. an even greater robber of joy is preoccupation with oneself because of ones sins. Yes, of course, we need to be concerned about our failures. BUT, knowing the Lord is near means we bring those sins to Him in repentance. We need to trust His Word that He has plunged them into the depths of His forgiveness. I'm thrilled that in His gentleness He does not deal with me as I deserve but forgives me for the sake of His Son. Just as God in His gentle love sent His Son to wash away my sins, so I'm to respond with gentleness toward my fellowman. God's gentleness in Christ is contagious. When we have it, we spread it to others.
prayer: Dear Lord, help me to be like Jesus ~ meek ~ lowly ~ loving ~ mild. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Do not be anxious about anything, but in everything, by prayer and petition, with thanksgiving, present your requests to God. And the peace of God, which transcends all understanding, will guard your hearts and your minds in Christ Jesus. (Philippians 4:6, 7)
reflection: "Don't be anxious about anything, " Paul said. I think we've all said, "Easier said than done." Who doesn't have cares, even in this joyous season? The experts tell us that during a holiday season like this, cares seem even greater. All around us we hear "Merry Christmas, " BUT often our lives are far from merry. Have you ever thought, that God is unconcerned about your cares? That's not the remedy Paul offers."Present your requests to God, " he says. God knows and cares and wants to do something about our cares. So He gently invites us, His children: "Tell me all about it. there is no fear I cannot remove. No burden I cannot help you carry. No broken heart I cannot heal. No tear so bitter I cannot wipe away. No sin, regardless how repeated, I have not forgiven." Paul reminds us to bring our cares to the Lord, "With Thanksgiving." Complaints are out of order. Can He who gave us the Savior withhold what we need in the changing scenes of life???
prayer: Dear Lord, help me carry everything to You in prayer with the confidence that is mine in Jesus. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: When the time had fully come, God sent His son, born of a woman, born under the law, that we might receive the full rights of sons. (Galatians 4:4, 5)
reflection: Jesus was "born of a woman, " ~ He was human ~ He was born a Jew ~ He was subject to God's law ~ He fulfilled it perfectly. Thus Jesus was a perfect sacrifice because, although He was fully human, He never sinned. His death brought freedom for us who were enslaved to sin so that we could be adopted into God's family. If Christ had not come, there would not be a Christian in the world. Imagine that!!!
prayer: Dear Lord, I thank You, for sending Jesus to set me free. Thank You for Your love. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: The life appeared; we have seen it and testify to it, and we proclaim to you the eternal life, which was with the Father and has appeared to us. ( 1 John 1:2)
reflection: An old legend tell how at midnight on Christmas Eve all the animals pause wherever they are and kneel. In this way they honor the Son of God, who once used their manger for His cradle. As we pause to kneel this Holy Season, let us TRULY remember why. Sometime I wish I could see Jesus as John did. Then I remember that its not the physical but the spiritual closeness of Jesus that counts. Through the Word, the Holy Spirit gives me eyes to see and a heart to believe in the incarnate Word of life. With His gift of faith, I see in the manger the eternal God who came to bring me eternal life. That's why I kneel before Him.
prayer: Dear Lord, I thank You for faith's sight. Help me to kneel in humble awe before Your gift of life. (Jesus Christ). Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: We proclaim to you what we have seen and heard, so that you may have fellowship with us. And our fellowship is with the Father and with His Son, Jesus Christ. (I John 1:3)
reflection: The word fellowship is a big one in the New Testament. It comes from a root meaning "to have things in common." Listen to what John is telling us, He says: through the Christ Child, I can have back what Adam and Eve once had with God. They shared in all His blessings. They walked with Him in all His ways. For them life was a perpetual heaven because it was a perfect relationship with God. There is only one way back to such a blessed fellowship with the Father. Only one way for sinners like me to stand next to God. Only one way to look at Him and see Him smiling at me. Only one way to stretch out my hand and have Him fill it with blessing after blessing. Only one way for me to close my eyes for the last time and open them in heaven. Through the baby in the Bethlehem manger and the Christ on the Calvary cross! He came to earth: He took on my flesh. He became my brother, to make me His brother in God's family. He came to seek and save a lost family. He came to pay for my sins and plunged Himself into my hell so that I could again be one with my Father.
prayer: Thank You, Lord Jesus, for restoring the fellowship I now enjoy with the Father. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Today in the town of David a Savior has been born to you; He is Christ the Lord. (Luke 2:11)
reflection: Take a moment for this thought, If Jesus had never been born, there'd be no salvation. Then Adam and Eve would still be crying, not only at Eden's door but in hell. Then the thief on the cross would have no answer to his plea for just a corner in paradise. Then Paul would still be the chief of sinners. Then you and I would be along with all sinners most miserable and sure only of punishment in a never-ending hell. If Jesus had never been born, I wouldn't be going to any services this Christmas Eve. Nor tomorrow or ever, because what would I have to sing to hear about, to rejoice about? There would be no message of hope for my eager ears to hear. Its bad enough to celebrate Christmas separated from loved ones. But just think if there were no Jesus and no promise of eternal life. There's a thought to make even the angels weep.
prayer: Dear Lord, help me sing tonight, "I am so glad when Christmas comes, the night of Jesus' birth." Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Thanks be to God for His indescribable Gift! (II Corinthians 9:15)
reflection: Once in a while we hear about the perfect gift for someone who has everything. BUT, what about the perfect gift for someone who has nothing and needs everything? That's what God gave me at Christmas. When God put His Son into the manger, He gave me everything, I needed for salvation. He gave me His Son from heaven to wash away my sins with His precious blood. I needed peace with God, He gave me the Prince of Peace, who brought back a blessed relationship with the Father. I needed power against sin, He gave me the Mighty Lord, who defeated Satan in the wilderness and even more so on the cross. How can the devil keep sin's handcuffs on me when Christ is the key that unlocks them? We often need comfort in life's sorrows, He gave us the living Savior, who wipes away our tears. We need assurance at the time of death, He gave us the risen Savior who has already conquered death, not just for Himself but for us. I had nothing, but with the gift of the Savior, God gave me everything I needed. Thanks be to God for His indescribable gift.
prayer: Thank you, Lord, for giving me just what I needed in the Savior, Help me praise Your love forever. Amen.

Thanks be to God for His indescribable Gift! (II Cor. 9:15)

Our Lesson for Today:
Once in a while we hear about the perfect gift for someone who has everything.
BUT, what about the perfect gift for someone who has nothing and needs everything?
That's what God gave me at Christmas...

When God put His Son into the manger, He gave me everything, I needed for salvation.
He gave me His Son from heaven to wash away my sins with His precious blood.
I needed peace with God, He gave me the Prince of Peace, who brought back a
blessed relationship with the Father.

I needed power against sin, He gave me the Mighty Lord, who defeated Satan in the 
wilderness and even more so on the cross. How can the devil keep sin's handcuffs on
me when Christ is the key that unlocks them?

We often need comfort in life's sorrows, He gave us the living Savior, who wipes away
our tears. We need assurance at the time of death, He gave us the risen Savior who has
already conquered death, not just for Himself but for us...

I had nothing, but with the gift of the Savior, God gave me everything I needed. 
Thanks be to God for His indescribable gift...

Prayer Suggestion:
Thank you, Lord, for giving me just what I needed
in the Savior, Help me praise Your love forever...Amen.

Ps. remember your greatest Christmas cheer comes 
when you dispense cheer... 
Pastor Alvin & Marcie Sather

The Lord said, "I am the way, the truth, and the life. No one can come to he father except through me." - John: 14:6

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: So they hurried off and found Mary and Joseph, and the baby, who was lying in the manger. (Luke 2:16)
reflection: Shepherds came to kneel at Jesus' manger bed. These were people who held one of the more menial jobs in life hurried to worship the newborn Savior. That comforts me ~ by bring the shepherds, God is reminding us that whatever our station in life, we have a Savior. From the moment of His birth, Jesus was ready to receive all sinners. That baby was born to save me. Mary and Joseph were there at Jesus' bed. From the little Scripture records about these two, we can learn something important about our faith. They didn't hesitate but took God at His word, even when His words seemed impossible. God help me to do the same, especially with His promise of salvation. Yes Jesus was laid in a manger, never before or again will the world see a baby like Him. ~ Only He was from all eternity ~ Only His birth was foretold centuries before ~ Only He was virgin born ~ Only at His birth did angels sing ~ Only He was born to die for His fellowman ~ Only He deserves our worship.
prayer: God, help me celebrate Christmas every day. Amen.

The Lord said, "I am the way, the truth, and the life. No one can come to the father except through me." - John: 14:6

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: and He will be called Wonderful Counselor. (Isaiah 9:6)
reflection: In Isaiah's day a counselor was one who stood at your side to offer good advice in all matters. Isn't that a good name for the babe of Bethlehem? Wouldn't we even say that the Christ of Christmas is a Counselor more wonderful than any other??? He needs no teachers but is Truth Himself. He needs no counselors but is the Counselor above every counselor. His advice is never lacking and is always correct. To wayward ones He says, "Your sins are forgiven." To weary ones He says, "Cast all your cares on Me because I care for you." To worried ones He says, "Will not My heavenly Father much more care for you?" To weeping ones He says, "Let not your heart be troubled, believe in Me." This Jesus has experienced my wrestling against sin and Satan ~ my pains and my death. Even something I shall never know, the agonies of hell. That's why the name Wonderful Counselor fits Him so well. He not only advises; He does. He did His work on the cross and now stands ready to help in every step of life as, my Wonderful Counselor.
prayer: Dear Lord and Savior, be with me as my Wonderful Counselor, to guide me in life and in death. Amen.

The Lord said, "I am the way, the truth, and the life. 

No one can come to the Father except through me." - John: 14:6

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: And He will be called. Mighty God. (Isaiah 9:6b)
reflection: When we look at the baby in the manger, one may fail to see Him as the might God. One may say, "that's God who is to be my Rock and my fortress?" "Why, a rock could so easily crush him in his helplessness." One may say, "That's God who is my shield and my defender?" "He himself must be defended from harm and shielded from the cold by His mother's arms." I would answer, "Yes my friend, that baby will become the Horn of our salvation, the Mighty God who with His power will toss our enemies of sin and death into the air." Let's see Him for who He truly is. That baby is the Mighty God who calms storms and heals men. Even more do we see His might when with His powerful Word He sends the devil packing in the wilderness. We also see His might when He shouts of sin's payment on the cross, "It is finished." Yes, we see His might even more when He leaves His tomb empty and assures us, "Because I live, you also will live." And yes even more do we see His might when He arms us for our daily battle against Satan by giving us the "Sword of the Spirit which is the Word of God." Yes, when Jesus, our Savior, stands at our side as the Mighty God, victory is always within reach. With Him we can face any foe.
prayer: Dear Lord, be with me as my Mighty God so that I may have power against all my enemies. Amen.

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: And He will be called. Everlasting Father. (Isaiah 9:6c)
reflection: Everlasting Father, is another name Isaiah gives the Christ Child. What tenderness, love, and comfort are in His name. To His followers the babe of Bethlehem is like a father because of what He does. He doesn't leave His people to fend for themselves. Instead, He does perfectly for them what an earthly father can only try to do for his children. An earthly father tries to provide what he thinks is best for his children. The Savior always provides what He knows is best. He's my Everlasting Father. Always He walks with me ~ Always His love forgives me ~ Always His power protects me ~ He'll be there to lead me even through the valley of the shadow to His heaven. My earthly father meant much to me. Jesus, my Everlasting Father, means so much more.
prayer: Dear Lord and Savior, take my hand and lead me as my Everlasting Father to Your heavenly home. Amen.

The Lord said, "I am the way, the truth, and the life. No one can come to the father except through me." - John: 14:6

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: And He will be called ~ Prince of peace. (Isaiah 9:6f)
reflection: Wouldn't it be great if one morning when we turned on the TV that the headlines were, "No War Anywhere in the World Today"? When Isaiah calls the Christ Child the "Prince of Peace." he has more in mind than world peace ~ He means more than the peace that would result if no nation anywhere had any nuclear weapons of chemical bombs. If every one of us choked off his selfishness and loved his neighbor as himself ~ if everyone practiced the Golden Rule, doing unto others as he wanted them to do to him. Such earthly peace would come about more if more people in this world were filled with Jesus' real peace. The heavenly Prince of Peace came to bring the peace that results when the war between God and man, cause by sin, is over. He came to prepare the peace that floods the heart when man knows God is his dear friend, not his dreaded Foe. He came to make possible the peace that assures the dying that heaven is their beautiful home, that their inevitable destination is not hell. Yes I agree Jesus' peace surpasses all understanding ~ It enables me to live in my tense world ~ It sustains me in moments of sorrow ~ It equips me to face eternity unafraid ~ Yes I still need outward peace on this earth, but even more soI need the kind the Christ Child prepared with His manger and cross.
prayer: Dear Lord, fill my heart with the peace that comes only through your payment for my sins. Amen

The Lord said, "I am the way, the truth, and the life. No one can come to the father except through me." - John: 14:6

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: You know with all your heart and soul that not one of the good promises the Lord your God gave you has failed. Every promise has been fulfilled. (Jos. 23:14)
reflection: What do you see when you look back at the highway of this past year? You know what I see? I see so many of my thoughts, words and deeds lying in the ditch like so much litter. How can I pick back up the trash of my words with which I've hurt people, not to mention my Savior? ~ How can I pay the fine for littering the road of life with my sinful words and deeds? Oh how I've blown another year. From the look back, I can only look up. ~ What do I see when I raise faith's eyes to Jesus, who is the same yesterday, today, and forever? ~ Wasn't He there each time I came with the penitent plea, "God be merciful to me a sinner"? Wasn't He there in His Word and Holy Supper to assure me: "Your sins are forgiven. Go in peace"? ~ Isn't He here today at the end of another year too one last time repeat His sweet promises to me? ~ Hasn't He kept His promises also for the lesser needs of my body? ~ Wont He continue to make all things work together for my good? That's right ~ not one of His good promises has failed. ~ That's why I comfortably close out the old year and confidently enter the new one.
prayer: Dear Lord, thanks for all Your mercies this past year. Please walk with me into the new one. Amen.

The Lord said, "I am the way, the truth, and the life. No one can come to the father except through me." - John: 14:6

subject: thoughts to live by
verse: Jesus is the same yesterday and today and forever. (Hebrews 13:8)
reflection: More of the same ~ that's what life seems to be for many of us. Oh yes, some may have new experiences and excitement this new year, but life for many of us will be one day strung behind the other with the same tasks hovering over us and the same troubles settling on our shoulders. It doesn't make much difference what number we write for the year. But let us thank God one thing never changes: Would we want a Lord who changes His mind and issues a recall for promises He made yesterday? Would we want, a Lord who forgets His full payment for all our sins and now demands that we cover sin's debt? Would we want, a Lord who closes the door to heaven on a whim that He once opened with His resurrection? More of the same! That's what we need and that's what we have in our Savior Jesus, who is the same yesterday and today and forever.
prayer: Dear Lord Jesus, fill our lives each day of this new year with more of Your unchanging love. Amen.
